title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?

The total ratio representing the number of photos Malachi took is 10+17=<<10+17=27>>27.
The difference in the ratios representing the number of photos Malachi took is 17-10=<<17-10=7>>7.
If each part of the ratio represents 2430/27=<<2430/27=90>>90 photos.
Malachi took 17*90 = <<17*90=1530>>1530 selfies this year.
Malachi took 10*90 = <<10*90=900>>900 selfies last year.
The difference is 1530-900= <<1530-900=630>>630. Answer: \boxed{630}.


Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?

Since the ratio of the number of photos he took this year to last year is 17:10, then the difference in the terms of the ratio representing the number of photos he took this year and last year is 17-10 = <<17-10=7>>7
The difference in the terms of the ratio representing the number of photos they took this year and last year is 7 out of 17+10 = 27
Since 27 represents 2430 photos, then 1 represents 2430/27 = <<2430/27=90>>90 photos
The difference in the terms of the ratio representing the number of selfies he took this year and last year is 7*90 = <<7*90=630>>630. Answer: \boxed{630}.


Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?

The fraction representing the number of selfies Malachi took last year is 10/(10+17)=10/27
Since he has 2430 photos in his phone gallery, the fraction representing the number of photos he took this year is 17/(10+17)=17/27
This year, Malachi took 17/27*2430 = 1530 photos.
Last year, he took 10/27*2430 = <<10/27*2430=900>>900 photos.
This year, Malachi took 1530-900 = <<1530-900=630>>630 more photos than he took last year. Answer: \boxed{630}.


Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?

The total ratio representing the number of photos Malachi took last year and this year is 10+17 = <<10+17=27>>27

7 parts of the ratio represent the increment in the number of photos Malachi took this year.
If each part represents 2430/27 = <<2430/27=90>>90 photos,
Then Malachi took 7*90 = <<7*90=630>>630 more photos this year than last year. Answer: \boxed{630}.


Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?

The total ratio representing the number of years Malachi has taken selfies is 10+17 = <<10+17=27>>27
From the total ratio representing the number of years Malachi has taken selfies, 1 part represents 2430/27 = <<2430/27=90>>90 photos
Malachi took 10 parts/years x 90 = <<10*90=900>>900 photos last year.
This year, Malachi took 17 parts/years x 90 = <<17*90=1530>>1530 photos.
He took 1530 - 900 = <<1530-900=630>>630 more photos this year than last year. Answer: \boxed{630}.


Question: In his phone gallery, Malachi has the number of selfies he took last year and this year in the ratio of 10:17. If he has 2430 photos in his gallery, how many more photos did he take this year than last year?
text:
The total ratio representing the number of selfies Malachi took last year and this year is 10+17 = <<10+17=27>>27.
The difference in the ratios representing the number of photos he took this year and last year is 17-10 = <<17-10=7>>7.
If each part of the ratio represents 2430/27 = <<2430/27=90>>90 photos.
Malachi took 17*90 = <<17*90=1530>>1530 selfies this year.
Malachi took 10*90 = <<10*90=900>>900 selfies last year.
The difference is 1530-900 = <<1530-900=630>>630. Answer: \boxed{630}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Danny has three picnics blankets. When they are unfolded they each have an area of 8 x 8. After he folds them up, their total area is 48 square feet. How many times did he fold them?

The unfolded area of one picnic blanket is 8 x 8 = <<8*8=64>>64 square feet.
Danny's three picnic blankets have a total unfolded area of 64 x 3 = <<64*3=192>>192 square feet.
Therefore, Danny had to fold his picnic blankets 192 / 48 = <<192/48=4>>4 times. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Danny helps his friends carpool to work. He has to drive 8 miles to the first friend's house, half that distance to the second friend's house, then 3 times the total distance driven so far to get to work. How many miles does Danny drive between the second friend's house and work?

First double the distance to the second friend's house: 8 miles * 1/2 = <<8*1/2=4>>4 miles
Then add the distance to the first friend's house: 4 miles + 8 miles = <<4+8=12>>12 miles
Then triple that distance to get the final distance: 12 miles * 3 = <<12*3=36>>36 miles. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: Danny helps his friends carpool to work. He has to drive 8 miles to the first friend's house, half that distance to the second friend's house, then 3 times the total distance driven so far to get to work. How many miles does Danny drive between the second friend's house and work?

First find the number of miles Danny drives on the first leg: 8 miles / 2 = <<8/2=4>>4 miles
Then find the total number of miles Danny drives for the first two legs: 8 miles + 4 miles = <<8+4=12>>12 miles
Then multiply that number by 3 to find how many miles Danny drives to work: 12 miles * 3 = <<12*3=36>>36 miles. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: Danny helps his friends carpool to work. He has to drive 8 miles to the first friend's house, half that distance to the second friend's house, then 3 times the total distance driven so far to get to work. How many miles does Danny drive between the second friend's house and work?

First find the distance between the second friend's house and the office: 8 miles * 1/2 = <<8*1/2=4>>4 miles
Then figure out the total distance driven from the first friend's house to the second friend's house: 8 miles + 4 miles = <<8+4=12>>12 miles
Then triple that distance to find the distance from the second friend's house to work: 12 miles * 3 = <<12*3=36>>36 miles. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: Danny helps his friends carpool to work. He has to drive 8 miles to the first friend's house, half that distance to the second friend's house, then 3 times the total distance driven so far to get to work. How many miles does Danny drive between the second friend's house and work?

First find the distance from the first friend's house to the second friend's house: 8 miles / 2 = <<8/2=4>>4 miles
Then add that distance to the distance from Danny's house to the first friend's house: 4 miles + 8 miles = <<4+8=12>>12 miles
Then multiply the total distance by 3 to find the distance Danny drives to work: 12 miles * 3 = <<12*3=36>>36 miles. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: Danny has three picnics blankets. When they are unfolded they each have an area of 8 x 8. After he folds them up, their total area is 48 square feet. How many times did he fold them?
text:
The unfolded area of one picnic blanket is 8 x 8 = 64 square feet. 
Danny's three picnic blankets have a total unfolded area of 64 x 3 = 192 square feet. 
Therefore, Danny had to fold his picnic blankets 192 / 48 = 4 times. Answer: \boxed{4}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?

In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red. So there are 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 red roses in each row.
The number of roses that are not red is 20 - 10 = <<20-10=10>>10 roses.
The number of white roses is 3/5 * 10 roses = <<3/5*10=6>>6 roses.
So, the number of roses that are pink in each row is 10 - 6 = <<10-6=4>>4 roses.
There are a total of 10 rows, so Mrs. Dawson's rose garden has 10 *4 = <<10*4=40>>40 pink roses. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?

In each row, there are 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 red roses.
So, 20 - 10 = <<20-10=10>>10 roses remain in each row after picking the red roses.
Ten roses are white.
So, there are (3/5) x 10 = <<3/5*10=6>>6 white roses in each row.
Therefore, 10 - 6 = <<10-6=4>>4 of them in each row are pink.
Hence, Mrs. Dawson has 10 x 4 = <<10*4=40>>40 pink roses in her garden. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?

In each row of roses, 1/2 x 20 = <<1/2*20=10>>10 roses are red.
The number of roses that are not red is 20 - 10 = <<20-10=10>>10.
Out of 10 roses, 3/5 x 10 = <<3/5*10=6>>6 roses are white.
The number of roses remaining after red and white roses are removed is 10 - 6 = <<10-6=4>>4 which are pink.
Therefore, there are a total of 4 x 10 = <<4*10=40>>40 pink roses in Mrs. Dawson's rose garden. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?

In each row, there are 1/2 x 20 = <<1/2*20=10>>10 red roses.
So, there are 20 - 10 = <<20-10=10>>10 roses left that are not red.
There are 3/5 x 10 = <<3/5*10=6>>6 roses that are white in each row.
Therefore, 10 - 6 = <<10-6=4>>4 roses are pink in each row.
Hence, the total number of pink roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden is 10 rows x 4 roses/row = <<10*4=40>>40 roses. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?

In each row, there are 20 roses * 1/2 of red = <<20*1/2=10>>10 red roses.
The remaining roses in each row are 20 roses - 10 roses = <<20-10=10>>10 roses.
There are 10 roses * 3/5 white roses = <<10*3/5=6>>6 white roses in each row.
So, there are 10 roses - 6 roses = <<10-6=4>>4 pink roses in each row.
Therefore, there are 10 rows * 4 pink roses = <<10*4=40>>40 pink roses at Mrs. Dawson’s rose garden. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: At Mrs. Dawson's rose garden, there are 10 rows of roses. In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, 3/5 of the remaining are white and the rest are pink. How many roses at Mrs. Dawson's rose garden are pink?
text:
In each row, there are 20 roses where 1/2 of these roses are red, so there are 20 * 1/2 = <<20*1/2=10>>10 red roses in each row.
The remaining roses in each row are 20 - 10 = <<20-10=10>>10 roses.
Out of these remaining roses, 3/5 are white, so there are 10 * 3/5 = <<10*3/5=6>>6 white roses in each row.
Therefore, the number of pink roses in each row is 10 - 6 = <<10-6=4>>4.
Since there are 10 rows, Mrs. Dawson's rose garden has a total of 10 * 4 = <<10*4=40>>40 pink roses. Answer: \boxed{40}.

title:

Question: Lena is making a collage with pictures of all her closest friends and newspaper clippings that are about their interests. She has found three clippings for each friend’s pictures. It takes her six drops of glue to stick down each clipping. Lena has already glued her seven closest friends’ pictures. How many drops of glue will she need for the newspaper clippings for her collage?

Lena has seven friends and she wants to stick down three clippings for each friend, so she will need 7 * 3 = <<7*3=21>>21 clippings.
Lena uses six drops of glue for each clipping, so she will need 21 * 6 = <<21*6=126>>126 drops of glue. Answer: \boxed{126}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: For every 100 additional people that board a spaceship, its speed is halved. If the speed of the spaceship with 200 people on board is 500km per hour, what is its speed in km/hr when there are 400 people on board?

For every 100 additional people that board the spaceship, its speed is halved. 

Initially, with 200 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is 500 km/hr. 

From this, we can deduce that when the number of people on board increases by 100, the speed of the spaceship is halved. 

So, when there are 300 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is 500/2 = <<500/2=250>>250 km/hr. 

Similarly, when there are 400 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is again halved, becoming 250/2 = <<250/2=125>>125 km/hr. Answer: \boxed{125}.


Question: For every 100 additional people that board a spaceship, its speed is halved. If the speed of the spaceship with 200 people on board is 500km per hour, what is its speed in km/hr when there are 400 people on board?

When there are 200 people on board, for every additional 100 people that board, the speed is halved. So when there are 300 people on board, the speed will be 500km/hr divided by 2 = <<500/2=250>>250km/hr.
When there are 400 people on board, another 100 people will have boarded, bringing the total number on board to 400 people.
So the speed will be halved once more to 250km/hr divided by 2 = <<250/2=125>>125km/hr. Answer: \boxed{125}.


Question: The spacecraft Gibraltar is a mountain-sized intergalactic vehicle for transporting equipment, building materials, and families to establish colonies on far-away planets.  At full capacity, the vehicle can carry 300 family units with four people per family.  The space flight is expected to take years, and it is expected that the size of families will grow during the space voyage.  Therefore, when the spacecraft leaves the earth, it will carry 100 people less than one-third of the ship's capacity.  How many people will be on the ship to start the journey?

The full capacity of the spacecraft is 300 family units * 4 people per family unit = <<300*4=1200>>1200 people.
One-third of the ship's capacity is 1200 people / 3 = <<1200/3=400>>400 people.
The number of people the spacecraft will carry is 400 people - 100 people = <<400-100=300>>300 people. Answer: \boxed{300}.


Question: The spacecraft Gibraltar is a mountain-sized intergalactic vehicle for transporting equipment, building materials, and families to establish colonies on far-away planets.  At full capacity, the vehicle can carry 300 family units with four people per family.  The space flight is expected to take years, and it is expected that the size of families will grow during the space voyage.  Therefore, when the spacecraft leaves the earth, it will carry 100 people less than one-third of the ship's capacity.  How many people will be on the ship to start the journey?

At full capacity, the spacecraft can carry 300 family units * 4 people per family unit = <<300*4=1200>>1200 people.
One-third of the ship's capacity is 1200 people / 3 = <<1200/3=400>>400 people.
Therefore, when the spacecraft leaves the Earth, there will be 400 people - 100 people = <<400-100=300>>300 people on board. Answer: \boxed{300}.


Question: The spacecraft Gibraltar is a mountain-sized intergalactic vehicle for transporting equipment, building materials, and families to establish colonies on far-away planets.  At full capacity, the vehicle can carry 300 family units with four people per family.  The space flight is expected to take years, and it is expected that the size of families will grow during the space voyage.  Therefore, when the spacecraft leaves the earth, it will carry 100 people less than one-third of the ship's capacity.  How many people will be on the ship to start the journey?

The spacecraft Gibraltar can carry 300 family units * 4 people per family = <<300*4=1200>>1200 people at full capacity.
One-third of the ship's capacity is 1200 people / 3 = <<1200/3=400>>400 people.
Therefore, when the spacecraft leaves the earth, it will carry 400 people - 100 people = <<400-100=300>>300 people.
So, there will be 300 people on the ship to start the journey. Answer: \boxed{300}.


Question: For every 100 additional people that board a spaceship, its speed is halved. If the speed of the spaceship with 200 people on board is 500km per hour, what is its speed in km/hr when there are 400 people on board?
text:
For every 100 additional people that board the spaceship, its speed is halved. 

Initially, with 200 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is 500 km/hr. 

From this, we can deduce that when the number of people on board increases by 100, the speed of the spaceship is halved. 

So, when there are 300 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is 500/2 = 250 km/hr. 

Similarly, when there are 400 people on board, the speed of the spaceship is again halved, becoming 250/2 = 125 km/hr. Answer: \boxed{125}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: To make a yellow score mixture, Taylor has to combine white and black scores in the ratio of 7:6. If she got 78 yellow scores, what's 2/3 of the difference between the number of black and white scores she used?

The total ratio representing the number of scores is 7+6 = <<7+6=13>>13
Taylor combined white and black scores to make 78, with the white scores looking like 7/13 * 78 = <<7/13*78=42>>42 scores.
The number of black scores that Taylor used is 78 - 42 = <<78-42=36>>36
The difference between the number of black and white scores she used is 42 - 36 = <<42-36=6>>6 scores.
Two-thirds of the difference between the number of black and white scores she used is 2/3 * 6 = <<2/3*6=4>>4. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: To make a yellow score mixture, Taylor has to combine white and black scores in the ratio of 7:6. If she got 78 yellow scores, what's 2/3 of the difference between the number of black and white scores she used?

The total ratio representing the number of white and black scores is 7+6 = <<7+6=13>>13
If T represent the whole, the fraction representing the number of scores Taylor used that is white is 7/13, the fraction representing the number of scores Taylor used that is black is 6/13.
The number of white scores Taylor used is 78*(7/13)= <<78*(7/13)=42>>42
The number of black scores Taylor used is 78*(6/13)= <<78*(6/13)=36>>36
The difference between the number of black and white scores Taylor used is 42-36 = <<42-36=6>>6
Two-thirds the difference between the number of black and white scores Taylor used is 2/3 * 6 = <<2/3*6=4>>4. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Miss Molly surveyed her class of 30 students about their favorite color. Half of the class answered green, one-third of the girls answered pink, and the rest of the class answered yellow. If there are 18 girls in the class, how many students like yellow best?

Half of the class is 30 / 2 = <<30/2=15>>15 students.
One-third of the girls answered, pink, so 18 / 3 = <<18/3=6>>6 girls answered pink.
Thus, 15 - 6 = <<15-6=9>>9 students answered yellow. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Miss Molly surveyed her class of 30 students about their favorite color. Half of the class answered green, one-third of the girls answered pink, and the rest of the class answered yellow. If there are 18 girls in the class, how many students like yellow best?

Out of the 30 students, half answered green which is 30 / 2 = <<30/2=15>>15 students.
One-third of the girls answered pink. So, 18 / 3 = <<18/3=6>>6 girls answered pink.
So, 15 - 6 = <<15-6=9>>9 students answered yellow. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Miss Molly surveyed her class of 30 students about their favorite color. Half of the class answered green, one-third of the girls answered pink, and the rest of the class answered yellow. If there are 18 girls in the class, how many students like yellow best?

Out of the 30 students in the class, half prefer green, or 30/2 = <<30/2=15>>15 students.
The girls constitute 18 of the 30 students, therefore 30-18 = <<30-18=12>>12 students are boys.
If the girls are 18, then the boys must be 30-18 = <<30-18=12>>12 students.
1/3 of the girls, or 1/3*18 = <<1/3*18=6>>6 girls, prefer the color pink.
The rest of the girls, or 18-6 = <<18-6=12>>12 girls, like yellow.
Since 30-15-6 = <<30-15-6=9>>9 students did not answer either green or pink, then 9/12 = <<9/12=0.75>>0.75, or 75%, of the boys did not answer.
Since there are 12 boys, then 75% of 12 = (0.75)*12 = <<(0.75)*12=9>>9 boys like yellow the best. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: To make a yellow score mixture, Taylor has to combine white and black scores in the ratio of 7:6. If she got 78 yellow scores, what's 2/3 of the difference between the number of black and white scores she used?
text:
The total ratio representing the number of scores is 7+6 = <<7+6=13>>13
Taylor combined white and black scores to make 78, with the white scores looking like 7/13 * 78 = <<7/13*78=42>>42 scores.
The number of black scores that Taylor used is 78 - 42 = <<78-42=36>>36
The difference between the number of black and white scores she used is 42 - 36 = <<42-36=6>>6 scores.
Two-thirds of the difference between the number of black and white scores she used is 2/3 * 6 = <<2/3*6=4>>4. Answer: \boxed{4}.

title:

Question: Jolene wants to raise some money to buy a bicycle.  She babysits for 4 families for $30 each.  She also washes 5 neighbors’ cars for $12 each.  How much did she raise so far?

Jolene babysat for 4 families for 4*$30=$<<4*30=120>>120.
She also got $12*5=$<<12*5=60>>60.
Therefore, Jolene raised a total of $120+$60=$<<120+60=180>>180. Answer: \boxed{180}.

Jolene washes 5 neighbors’ cars, for $12 each, so she makes 5*12 = $<<5*12=60>>60.
So in total, Jolene raises 120+60 = $<<120+60=180>>180. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Jolene wants to raise some money to buy a bicycle.  She babysits for 4 families for $30 each.  She also washes 5 neighbors’ cars for $12 each.  How much did she raise so far?
text:
Jolene earns $30 for each family she babysits for, and she babysits for 4 families, so she earns $30 x 4 = $<<30*4=120>>120 from babysitting. 
Jolene earns $12 for each car she washes, and she washes 5 cars, so she earns $12 x 5 = $<<12*5=60>>60 from washing cars. 
Therefore, she has raised a total of $120 + $60 = $<<120+60=180>>180 so far. Answer: \boxed{180}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).

Jeff has 16 - 4 = <<16-4=12>>12 GB of storage left.
Jeff has 12 x 1000 = <<12*1000=12000>>12,000 MB of storage left.
Jeff can store 12000 / 30 = <<12000/30=400>>400 songs on his phone. Answer: \boxed{400}.


Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).

Jeff has 16000 MB of storage on his phone because 16 x 1000 = <<16*1000=16000>>16,000
He has 12 GB of storage left because 16 - 4 = <<16-4=12>>12
He has 12,000 MB of storage left because 12 x 1000 = <<12000=12000>>12,000
He can store 400 songs because 12,000 / 30 = <<12000/30=400>>400. Answer: \boxed{400}.


Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).

Jeff's phone has 16 GB x 1000 MB/GB = <<16*1000=16000>>16000 MB.
Jeff has 16000 MB - 4000 MB = <<16000-4000=12000>>12000 MB of storage left.
Therefore, Jeff can store 12000MB / 30MB/song = <<12000/30=400>>400 songs on his phone. Answer: \boxed{400}.


Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).

Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).

Jeff has 16 GB * 1000 MB/GB = <<16*1000=16000>>16000 MB of storage on his phone.
Jeff has 16000 MB - 4 GB * 1000 MB/GB = <<16000-4*1000=12000>>12000 MB of storage left on his phone.
Jeff can store 12000 MB / 30 MB/song = <<12000/30=400>>400 songs on his phone. Answer: \boxed{400}.


Question: Jeff has 16 GB of storage on his phone. He is already using 4 GB. If a song takes up about 30MB of storage, how many songs can Jeff store on his phone? (There are 1000 MB in a GB).
text:
Jeff has 16 GB * 1000 MB/GB = <<16*1000=16000>>16000 MB of storage on his phone.

Jeff can store 12000 MB / 30 MB/song = <<12000/30=400>>400 songs on his phone. Answer: \boxed{400}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A classroom of 15 students turned in essays on Friday morning. The first 5 students each turned in essays with 2 pages. The next 5 students each turned in essays with 3 pages. The last 5 students each turned in essays with 1 page. What is the average page count per essay for the 15 students?

The first 5 students turned in a total of 5 * 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 pages.
The next 5 students turned in a total of 5 * 3 = <<5*3=15>>15 pages.
The last 5 students turned in a total of 5 * 1 = <<5*1=5>>5 pages.
The total page count is 10 + 15 + 5 = <<10+15+5=30>>30 pages.
The average page count per essay is 30 / 15 = <<30/15=2>>2 pages. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A classroom of 15 students turned in essays on Friday morning. The first 5 students each turned in essays with 2 pages. The next 5 students each turned in essays with 3 pages. In total, the students turned in 10 + 15 + 5 = <<10+15+5=30>>30 pages.
Therefore, the average page count per essay is 30 / 15 = <<30/15=2>>2 pages. Answer: \boxed{2}.

There are 5 students with 1 page essays, so that’s 5 * 1 = <<5*1=5>>5 pages.

The last 5 students each turned in essays with 1 page. What is the average page count per essay for the 15 students?

The last 5 students turned in a total of 5 × 1 = <<5*1=5>>5 pages.

The last 5 students each turned in essays with 1 page. What is the average page count per essay for the 15 students?
text:
The first 5 students turned in 5 * 2 = 10 pages.
The next 5 students turned in 5 * 3 = 15 pages.
The last 5 students turned in 5 * 1 = 5 pages.
The total page count is 10 + 15 + 5 = 30 pages.
The average page count per essay is 30 / 15 = 2 pages. Answer: \boxed{2}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?

First find the total number of months the loan will last: 20 years * 12 months/year = <<20*12=240>>240 months
Then divide the total cost of the house by the number of months to find the monthly payment: $480,000 / 240 months = $<<480000/240=2000>>2000/month
Then divide the total cost of the trailer by the number of months to find the monthly payment: $120,000 / 240 months = $<<120000/240=500>>500/month
Then subtract the trailer's monthly payment from the house's monthly payment to find the difference: $2000/month - $500/month = $<<2000-500=1500>>1500/month. Answer: \boxed{1500}.


Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?

First find the total number of payments for each loan: 20 years * 12 months/year = <<20*12=240>>240 months
Then subtract the cost of the trailer loan from the cost of the house loan to find the difference in monthly payments: $480,000 - $120,000 = $<<480000-120000=360000>>360,000
Then divide the difference in cost by the number of payments to find the difference in monthly payment: $360,000 / 240 months = $<<360000/240=1500>>1500. Answer: \boxed{1500}.


Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?

To calculate the monthly payment on the house, we need to divide the total cost of the house by the number of months in 20 years: $480,000 / (20*12) = $<<480000/(20*12)=2000>>2000 per month.
To calculate the monthly payment on the trailer, we need to divide the total cost of the trailer by the number of months in 20 years: $120,000 / (20*12) = $<<120000/(20*12)=500>>500 per month.
The monthly payment on the house is $2000 - $500 = $<<2000-500=1500>>1500 more than the trailer. Answer: \boxed{1500}.


Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?

First, we need to calculate the total number of monthly payments for each loan. Since both loans are paid off over 20 years, and there are 12 months in a year, there will be 20 * 12 = <<20*12=240>>240 monthly payments for each loan.
Next, we need to calculate the monthly payment for each loan. To do this, we divide the total cost of the loan by the number of monthly payments. For the house loan, the monthly payment is $480,000 / 240 = $<<480000/240=2000>>2000. For the trailer loan, the monthly payment is $120,000 / 240 = $<<120000/240=500>>500.
Finally, we subtract the monthly payment for the trailer loan from the monthly payment for the house loan to find the difference: $2000 - $500 = $<<2000-500=1500>>1500.
Therefore, the monthly payment on the house is $1500 more than the monthly payment on the trailer. Answer: \boxed{1500}.


Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?

The house will be paid off over 20 years at 12 payments per year, for a total of 20 * 12 = <<20*12=240>>240 payments.
The cost of the house per payment will be $480,000 / 240 payments = $2000 per payment.
The trailer will be paid off over 20 years at 12 payments per year, for a total of 20 * 12 = <<20*12=240>>240 payments.
The cost of the trailer per payment will be $120,000 / 240 payments = $<<120000/240=500>>500 per payment.
Thus, the monthly payment on the house is $2000 - $500 = $<<2000-500=1500>>1500 higher than the monthly payment on the trailer. Answer: \boxed{1500}.


Question: Jane is trying to decide whether to buy a house or a trailer. A house costs $480,000 and a trailer costs $120,000. Each loan will be paid in monthly installments over 20 years. How much more is the monthly payment on the house compared to the trailer?
text:
To find the monthly payment on the house, divide the total cost of the house by the total number of months in 20 years: $480,000 / (20*12) = $2000/month. 
To find the monthly payment on the trailer, divide the total cost of the trailer by the total number of months in 20 years: $120,000 / (20*12) = $500/month. 
The monthly payment on the house is $2000 - $500 = $1500/month more than the trailer. Answer: \boxed{1500}.
